Key Arguments: The complainant disputes the findings of the Office of the Australian Information Commissioner (OAIC) regarding a privacy complaint against Australia Post.
The complainant argues that video evidence contradicts the OAIC's findings that there was no interference with privacy.
The complainant believes that Australia Post intentionally held onto their documents and breached their privacy.
The complainant challenges the OAIC's interpretation of 'collection' and 'holding' of personal information under the Privacy Act.
The complainant requests a formal investigation into the incident, citing video evidence and personal loss.
Notable Quotes: This video evidence clearly shows that the Australia Post member of staff intentionally held onto my documents and refused to return them when requested to do so.
Your Letter does not appear to be a good faith assessment of this matter pursuant to your statutory obligations under the Privacy Act.
I request that you review your decision not to investigate the breach of my privacy and thereafter agree to conduct an investigation in good faith under s40 of the Privacy Act.
